column22: Describes the intention of how one or more practitioners intend to deliver care for a particular patient, group or community for a period of time, possibly limited to care for a specific condition or set of conditions.

column20: Action to occur as part of plan
column22: Identifies a planned action to occur as part of the plan.  For example, a medication to be used, lab tests to perform, self-monitoring, education, etc.
column26: Allows systems to prompt for performance of planned activities, and validate plans against best practice.
column42: cpl-3:Provide a reference or detail, not both {null}

column22: Resources that describe follow-on actions resulting from the plan, such as drug prescriptions, encounter records, appointments, etc.
column26: Links plan to resulting actions.

column22: A simple summary of a planned activity suitable for a general care plan system (e.g. form driven) that doesn't know about specific resources such as procedure etc.
column26: Details in a simple form for generic care plan systems.

column20: diet | drug | encounter | observation | procedure | supply | other
column22: High-level categorization of the type of activity in a care plan.

column30: High-level categorization of the type of activity in a care plan.

column22: Detailed description of the type of planned activity; e.g. What lab test, what procedure, what kind of encounter.
column24: Tends to be less relevant for activities involving particular products.  Codes should not convey negation - use "prohibited" instead.
column26: Allows matching performed to planned as well as validation against protocols.
column30: Detailed description of the type of activity; e.g. What lab test, what procedure, what kind of encounter.

column22: Identifies the quantity expected to be consumed in a given day.
column26: Allows rough dose checking.

column20: Extra info describing activity to perform
column22: This provides a textual description of constraints on the intended activity occurrence, including relation to other activities.  It may also include objectives, pre-conditions and end-conditions.  Finally, it may convey specifics about the activity such as body site, method, route, etc.

column26: Helps in planning of activity.

column22: Identifies the food, drug or other product to be consumed or supplied in the activity.
column30: A product supplied or administered as part of a care plan activity.

column22: If true, indicates that the described activity is one that must NOT be engaged in when following the plan.
column26: Captures intention to not do something that may have been previously typical.

column22: Identifies the quantity expected to be supplied, administered or consumed by the subject.
Provides the rationale that drove the inclusion of this particular activity as part of the plan.
column24: This could be a diagnosis code.  If a full condition record exists or additional detail is needed, use reasonCondition instead.
column30: Identifies why a care plan activity is needed.  Can include any health condition codes as well as such concepts as "general wellness", prophylaxis, surgical preparation, etc.

column22: Provides the health condition(s) that drove the inclusion of this particular activity as part of the plan.
column24: Conditions can be identified at the activity level that are not identified as reasons for the overall plan.

column22: The period, timing or frequency upon which the described activity is to occur.
column26: Allows prompting for activities and detection of missed planned activities.

column20: not-started | scheduled | in-progress | on-hold | completed | cancelled
column22: Identifies what progress is being made for the specific activity.
column24: Some aspects of status can be inferred based on the resources linked in actionTaken.  Note that "status" is only as current as the plan was most recently updated.
column26: Indicates progress against the plan, whether the activity is still relevant for the plan.
column30: Indicates where the activity is at in its overall life cycle.
column44: .statusCode not-started = new scheduled = not-started (and fulfillment relationship to appointent) in-progress = active on-hold = suspended completed = completed cancelled = aborted

column22: Provides reason why the activity isn't yet started, is on hold, was cancelled, etc.
column24: Will generally not be present if status is "complete".  Be sure to prompt to update this (or at least remove the existing value) if the status is changed.
column30: Describes why the current activity has the status it does; e.g. "Recovering from injury" as a reason for non-started or on-hold, "Patient does not enjoy activity" as a reason for cancelling a planned activity.

column43: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column23: Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care team, such as "Primary care physician", "Trained social worker counselor", "Caregiver", etc.
column25: Roles may sometimes be inferred by type of Practitioner.  These are relationships that hold only within the context of the care team.  General relationships should be handled as properties of the Patient resource directly.
column31: Indicates specific responsibility of an individual within the care team, such as Primary physician, Team coordinator, Caregiver, etc.
column43: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column23: Indicates when the team did (or is intended to) come into effect and end.
column27: Allows tracking what team(s) are in effect at a particular time.
column43: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column23: Describes why the care team exists.
column31: Indicates the reason for the care team.
column43: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column23: Condition(s) that this care team addresses.
column43: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column23: Indicates the current state of the care team.
column25: This element is labeled as a modifier because the status contains the code entered-in-error that marks the care team as not currently valid.
column31: Indicates whether the team is current , represents future intentions or is now a historical record.
column43: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column23: Identifies the patient or group whose intended care is handled by the team.
column27:
Allows the team to care for a group (e.g. marriage) therapy. 
Allows for an organization to designate a team such as the PICC line team.
column43: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column21: A contact detail for the care team (that applies to all members)
column23: A central contact detail for the care team (that applies to all members).
column25: The ContactPoint.use code of home is not appropriate to use. These contacts are not the contact details of individual care team members.
column43: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}

column21: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
column23: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
column25: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.
column43: ele-1:All FHIR elements must have a @value or children {hasValue() or (children().count() > id.count())}
